currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and ear from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difefremce between me working in a factory or getting paid to play foorball. Bit

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Payiong student athletes to pay spoets is about as American as it gets

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worhtwhile for a young pertson to stay in school?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" econb

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete i

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is economics, pure and s

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is economics, pure and simple.In fact, 
The only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.


It is about time that we let market forces determine w

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and eanr from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worker summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

Paying student athletes to pay sports is about as American as it gets. It is a way to reward the best and brightest for their efforts. It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.


It is about time that we let market forces determine who plays where in co

It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.


It is about time that we let market forces determine who plays where in college. If a school wants to pay its players, let it. If a school wants to pay its players more than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players less than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players nothing, let it.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.


It is about time that we let market forces determine who plays where in college. If a school wants to pay its players, let it. If a school wants to pay its players more than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players less than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players nothing, let it.

It's called free ent

It is a way to encourage the best and brightest to stay in school. It is a way to keep the best and brightest from being lured away by professional sports agents or teams. 

Who could possibly object to making it financially worthwhile for a young person to stay in school? Karl Marx?

Getting paid to compete does not "distort" economics as McDavis claims, getting paid to compete is the essence of economics. In fact, te only thing that might distort the economics of college sports is the NCAA's rules against paying student athletes.


It is about time that we let market forces determine who plays where in college. If a school wants to pay its players, let it. If a school wants to pay its players more than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players less than other schools, let it. If a school wants to pay its players nothing, let it.

It's called free enterprise.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

My parents encouraged me to work and earn from an early age. From the age of 12 I had a paper route, got my working papers at 16, and worked summers in the factory where my grandfather worked. I gave about 3/4 to my Mom to help with the expenses. I was never that good at sports, but fail to see the difference between me working in a factory or getting paid to play football. Each is a paying job which a young person is lucky to have.

It's called free enterprise.
